case_name: M/s. Bellapu Audeyya and Chilla Pitchayya v. Income-tax Officer, Nellore Circle

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Y. Narayana Chetty, one of the partners of the Prabhat Textiles filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madras, No. 613 of 1952, against respondent I under Art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed that the High Court, should issue a writ of prohibition or any other appropriate writ, order or direction prohibiting the first respondent from companytinuing the proceedings as per his numberice of August 14, 1951, and from enforcing the order of fresh assessment passed in the said proceedings oil August 14, 1952, in regard to the assessment year 1943-1944.

anchor.surface_text: All the three firms were carrying on business in yarn and cloth and all of them were registered under s. 26A of the Act. It appears that for the purpose of assessing the income of these firms for the years 1943-44 and 1944-45, respondent 1 was satisfied on making enquiries that each of the three firms was a separate entity and so separate assessment orders were passed in respect of the income of each one of them for the said two years.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this finding, respondent I cancelled the registration of the said firm under r. 6B of the Income-tax Rules and passed fresh orders of assessment against the said firm on the basis that it was an unregistered firm for the assessment years 1943-44 and 1944-45 on August 14, 1952, and February 25, 1953, respectively. Similar action was taken by respondent I in respect of the two other firms on the same dates.

issues.text: whether the proceedings taken under s. 34 of the Act are invalid because the notice required to be issued under the said section has not been issued against the assessees contemplated therein (firm or individual partners)

anchor.surface_text: The first point raised by Mr. Sastri is that the proceedings taken by respondent I under s. 34 of the Act are invalid because the notice required to be issued under the said section has not been issued against the assessees contemplated therein. In the present case the Income-tax Officer has purported to act under s. 34 I  a  against the three firms.

issues.text: whether the Income-tax Officer was bound to issue notices to individual partners of the firms because at the material time all the firms had been dissolved

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged that the Income-tax Officer was bound to issue notices to individual partners of the firms because at the material time all the firms had been dissolved. Mr. Sastri concedes that under s. 63 (2) a notice or requisition under the Act may in the case of a firm be addressed to any member of the firm but his contention is that this applies to a firm in existence and not to a firm dissolved.

issues.text: if a firm has been registered under s. 26A, when can such registration be cancelled (only under s.23(4) or also under r.6B for fictitious firm; is r.6B ultra vires)

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision in this connection is if a firm has been registered under s. 26A, when can such registration be cancelled ? The appellant suggests that the only cases in which such registration can be cancelled are those prescribed in s. 23 (4) . We have no doubt that this argument is fallacious.

issues.text: whether the revised assessment is completely illogical and therefore illegal, in each case inasmuch as the original assessment remains on the basis that the firms are registered and the fresh assessment on escaped income on the basis that the firms are unregistered

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s.34 invalid because notice required under s.34 not issued against assessees contemplated therein (individual partners, not firm)

anchor.surface_text: The first point raised by Mr. Sastri is that the proceedings taken by respondent I under s. 34 of the Act are invalid because the notice required to be issued under the said section has not been issued against the assessees contemplated therein. In the present case the Income-tax Officer has purported to act under s. 34 I  a  against the three firms.

arguments.court_reasoning: Firm is assessee under s.3 (charging section), s.2(2) 'person' includes firm per General Clauses Act s.3(42); assessment process under ss.22-23 treats firm as assessee; s.23(5) allocates to partners but firm remains assessee.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34(1)(a) defective because issued against firm, not individual partners who are liable to pay tax per s.23(5)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri contends that this notice is defective because it purports to be issued Against the firm and notice has been issued against the respective partners of the firm. According to Mr. Sastri the assessee who is entitled to a notice under s. 34 1  a  is not the firm but each individual partner of the firm.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.23(5) determines partners' shares from firm's total income; firm is initial assessee; clarified by 1956 amendment.

arguments.claim: Assessee under s.2(2) means person by whom tax payable, i.e., individual partners of registered firm under s.23(5)

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument Mr. Sastri has referred us to the definition of the word assessee under s. 2, cl.  2  as it stood prior to the amendment of 1953. Under the said clause, assessee meant person by whom income-tax is clearly payable.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.23(4) is penalty for genuine firm defaults; r.6B corrects erroneous grant to fictitious firm; no inconsistency.

arguments.claim: Revised assessment illegal as illogical: original assessment treats firms as registered, escaped income as unregistered
arguments.court_reasoning: To be raised in statutory appeals under Act, including s.27 applications; does not raise jurisdiction for Art.226 writ.

arguments.claim: Writ discretionary; HC refused discretion, SC should not interfere

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kripal for the respondent sought to raise three preliminary objections. He urged that the issue of a writ is a discretionary matter and since the High Court has refused to exercise its discretion in favour of the appellants the appeals would be virtually incompetent inasmuch as this Court would be slow to interfere with the exercise of discretion by the High Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not considered as merits decided against appellants.

arguments.claim: Art.226 petitions incompetent due to alternative effective remedy (appeals filed, s.27 applications)

anchor.surface_text: He also argued that the original petitions to the High Court are incompetent under Art. 226 since under the Act the appellants had an alternative effective remedy available to them in the form of appeals against the impugned orders and in fact they had filed such appeals and had also made applications under s. 27 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not considered as merits decided against appellants.

arguments.claim: High Court no jurisdiction to issue writ of prohibition against tax authorities
arguments.court_reasoning: Not considered as merits decided against appellants.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34 is condition precedent to valid reassessment; invalid notice voids proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that the service of the requisite notice on the assessee is a condition precedent to the validity Of any reassessment made under s. 34 and if a valid notice is not issued as required, proceedings taken by the Income-tax Officer in pursuance of an invalid notice and subsequent orders of reassessment passed by him would be void and inoperative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r to S. 23 4 . This subsection provides If any person fails to make the return required by any numberice given under subsection  2  of section 22 and

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed, cites precedents; but notice here valid as served on firm.

arguments.claim: Firm is assessee for s.34 notice

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this contention is well- founded. The notice prescribed by s. 34 cannot be regarded as a mere procedural requirement it is only if the said notice is served on the assessee as required that the lncome-tax Officer would be justified in taking proceedings against him.

arguments.claim: r.6B valid, not ultra vires; for fictitious firms distinct from s.23(4)

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision in this connection is if a firm has been registered under s. 26A, when can such registration be cancelled ? The appellant suggests that the only cases in which such registration can be cancelled are those prescribed in s. 23 (4) . We have no doubt that this argument is fallacious.

arguments.claim: No notice required under r.6B if opportunity given; here given

holdings.text: The notice prescribed by s. 34 cannot be regarded as a mere procedural requirement; it is only if the said notice is served on the assessee as required that the Income-tax Officer would be justified in taking proceedings against him. If no notice is issued or if the notice issued is shown to be invalid then the validity of the proceedings taken by the Income-tax Officer without a notice or in pursuance of an invalid notice would be illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this contention is well- founded. The notice prescribed by s. 34 cannot be regarded as a mere procedural requirement it is only if the said notice is served on the assessee as required that the Income-tax Officer would be justified in taking proceedings against him. If no

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with petitioner's contention on condition precedent principle, citing Bombay and Calcutta High Court precedents; applies to facts where notice was served.

holdings.text: A firm is an assessee under s.34(1)(a); notice issued to and served on firm is valid; not required to individual partners.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, therefore, think that the appellants argument that the notice issued against the firm and served on the appellant was invalid under s. 34 1 a can be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 charges tax on firm; s.2(2) 'assessee' includes firm as 'person' per General Clauses Act; ss.22-23 treat firm as assessee; s.23(5) allocates shares but firm remains assessee.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer not bound to issue notices to individual partners post-dissolution; s.63(2) applies; proceedings valid as main appellant served and no grievance from others.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that it is not open to the appellants to contend that the proceedings taken by the Income-tax Officer under s. 34 1 a are invalid in that notices of these proceedings have not been served on the other alleged partners of the firms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants should have notified discontinuance under s.25(2); main appellant served personally; ITO found only two real partners, one unchallenged.

holdings.text: Rule 6B is intra vires, not inconsistent with Act; intended to carry out purpose of s.26A by cancelling registration granted to fictitious firm erroneously.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Framed under s.59 with statutory effect; distinct from s.23(4) penalty for genuine firm defaults; corrects erroneous registration of non-existent firm.

holdings.text: Cancellation under r.6B valid where opportunity to show firm genuine given, as here conceded.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural justice satisfied despite no mandatory notice in r.6B; appellant concedes opportunity given.

holdings.text: Contention of illogical revised assessment cannot be urged in Art.226 writ petition as does not raise jurisdiction question.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Matter concerns merits, to be raised in statutory appeals and s.27 applications.

T., Madras  1  where this Court has held that rules  2  and  6  of the rules framed under s. 59 of the Indian Income-tax Act are not ultra vires the rule- making authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: rules 2 and 6 of the rules framed under s. 59 of the Indian Income-tax Act are ultra vires the rule-making authority.
